Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 Robot Operating System (ROS)
ROS is not an operating system. It is a meta-Operating
System
ROS is running on top of another operating system (Linux)

Contains a collection of software, packaging, and building
tools
Suitable for distributed inter-process/inter-machine
communication
Can be used across networks (TCP/IP)

Provides tools for data analysis and debugging during run-time
Allows debugging under a distributed environment

Support various languages such as C++ and Python
We are going to use Python in this class
For CS, it should take about 5 hours to learn enough Python
for this class

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 Robot Operating System (ROS)

ROS is not an actual OS but has the same functionalities as
an OS
Supply interprocess communication
Signal/interrupt to processes

All major functionalities are broken up into a number of nodes
Each node runs as a separate process
Nodes communicate with each other using messages

Matchmaking between nodes is done by the ROS Master
(roscore)

Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 How ROS Works?

camera node
Performs hardware abstraction to support all kinds of USB
cameras
Turn the data from camera into a standard image format

Tells the ROS Master
I wants to publish images on topic image

cmvision node
Performs objects detection based on blob of colors
Turn an image into an array of coordinate of detected objects

Tells the ROS Master
I want to subscribe to receive images from the topic image
I also want to publish blobs on topic blobs

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 How ROS Works?

control node
Make decisions to turn left/right based on an array of
coordinates
Tells the ROS Master
I want to subscribe to receive blobs from the topic blobs
I also want to publish velocities on topic velocity

kobuki node
Performs hardware abstractions
Motor controller, motor feedback, sensors

Tells the ROS Master
I want to subscribe to receive velocities from the topic velocity

Note: the order does not matter

Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 ROS Nodes

A node is a process that performs some computations.
We typically divide the entire software functionality into
different modules
Single Node
Color image to array of coordinate in one program

Multiple Nodes:
Color image to black and white
Black and white to coordinate

Nodes are combined together into a graph and communicate
with one another using streaming topics
These nodes are meant to operate at a fine-grained scale
A robot control system usually comprise of many nodes.

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 ROS Node Examples
gscam node:
Communicates with integrated web camera at the hardware
level
Captures images and publishes on topic image
Note that a video is simply a series of images

cmvision node:
Subscribes to the topic image
Tries to find blobs of specific color for every image received
Publishes locations and sizes of blobs on topic blobs

control node:
Subscribes to the topic blob
Decides what to do
Publishes velocities to move robot

kobuki node:
Subscribes to the topic velocity
Tells kobuki robot what to do based on velocities received
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 ROS Topics

Topics are named buses over which nodes exchange messages
There can be hundreds of topics at a time

Topics have anonymous publish/subscribe semantics
A subscriber does not care which node published the data it
receives
A publisher does not care which node subscribes to the data it
publishes.

There can be multiple publishers and subscribers to a topic
Each topic is strongly typed by the ROS message it transports
Transport is done using TCP or UDP
Can be between multiple machines over networks

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Introduction to Robot Operating System (ROS)

 ROS Messages
Nodes communicate with each other by publishing messages
to topics
Publishers publish data to topics
Subscribers consume data from topics

A message is a simple data structure, comprising typed fields.
Similarly to data type in programming:
std msgs/Int32
std msgs/Float32
std msgs/String
std msgs/Empty

The numbers at the end indicates number of bits
Reference to standard messages (std msgs) can be found at
http://wiki.ros.org/std_msgs
